sentence: After a 75% rise since the March 23 lows of this year, at the current price of around $341 per share we believe Intuit stock (NASDAQ: INTU) has reached its near term potential based on its historic P/E Multiple.
Intuit, a financial, accounting, and tax preparation software provider, has seen its stock rally from $195 to $341 off the recent bottom compared to the S&P which moved around 55%.
It is leading the overall market as investors are positive about software stocks in general, and also the industry is not directly impacted by the Covid-19 crisis.
Further, the stock is up 24% from levels seen at the end of FY 2019 (FY August – July).
Intuit’s stock has surpassed the level it was at before the drop in February due to the coronavirus outbreak becoming a pandemic.
This seems to make it fully valued as, in reality, demand and revenue growth will likely be lower than last year.
Some of this rise of the last 2 years is justified by the roughly 31% growth seen in Intuit’s revenues from 2017 to 2019, which translated into a 58% growth in Net Income.
The higher growth in the net income figure could be attributed to the one-time higher income tax in FY 2017 due to the enactment of the U.S Tax Act, which weighed on the margins.
While the company has seen steady revenue and earnings growth over recent years, its P/E multiple has increased.
We believe the stock is unlikely to see a significant upside after the potential weakness from a recession-driven by the Covid outbreak.
Our dashboard What Factors Drove 155% Change In Intuit Stock Between 2017 And Now?
has the underlying numbers.
Intuit’s P/E multiple changed from around 35x at the end of FY 2017 to about 46x in FY 2019.
While the company’s P/E is just below 57x now, there is a downside risk when the current P/E is compared to levels seen in the past years.
P/E of around 46x at the end of FY 2019 and P/E of 39x at the end of FY 2018.
So what’s the likely trigger and timing for the downside?
Intuit offers financial, accounting, and tax preparation software and related services for small businesses, accountants, and individuals.

The Covid-19 crisis negatively impacted its small businesses and individual consumers segment, as many small businesses were closed or have scaled back their offerings, mainly driven by lower consumer demand and relaxation in the tax-filing deadline by the Internal Revenue Service (IRS) and all states.
This is likely to negatively affect the company’s top line as it derives most of its business from the segment (around 93% in 2019).
We believe Intuit’s Q1 FY 2021 (FY Aug-July) results will confirm this reality with a drop in both small business & self-employed segment and consumer division revenues.
However, over the coming weeks, we expect continued improvement in demand and subdued growth in the number of new Covid-19 cases in the U.S. to buoy market expectations.

Following the Fed stimulus — which helped to set a floor on fear — the market has been willing to “look through” the current weak period and take a longer-term view, with investors now mainly focusing their attention on 2021 results.
Though market sentiment can be fickle, and evidence of a sustained uptick in new cases could spook investors once again.
What if you’re looking for a more balanced portfolio instead?

Here’s a top-quality portfolio to outperform the market, with over 100% return since 2016, versus 55% for the S&P 500, Comprised of companies with strong revenue growth, healthy profits, lots of cash, and low risk.
It has outperformed the broader market year after year, consistently.
